1219. Chamberlin Laura Violet (Mrs. Selden C.)
1. Your full name: Laura Violet Chamberlin (Mrs.)
2. Your address: Kelotarn.
3. Date: April 7th.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Cumberland Ontario.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: James Devine Blacksmith.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): March 1918.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.). 22 years.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: I married one of the Western Bachelors who had come here in 1908.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
Chamberlin, Laura V.
Kilgore.

To Sask., March, 1923.

1. Your full name: Laura Violet Chamberlin (Mrs. Selden)
2. Your address: Kilgore
3. Date: Apr. 7th
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and occupation)
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   March 1913
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates whenever possible.

I married one of the Western Bochhorns who had come here in 1908.

32 years

How did you learn about the West? (Through other people) I am about 127.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people) I am about 127.
12. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought it OK.

13. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

Train CPR

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the trip, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other events etc.)

Our train was 48 hours late. The conductor wouldn't let us off at Moose Jaw so we had to go to Swift Current and come back next day. Swift Current was crowded so couldn't get a room in a hotel and all trains were late so we didn't get back to Moose Jaw until late next day.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Right here on our Homestead

32 - 14 - 6 W 3rd

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

The flats as it was known then.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Farming
Train C.P.R.

They thought it was K.

Arrived at our hotel at 9pm last night. We had a good day without any mishaps. Our rooms were clean and quiet. The food was excellent, and all in all we had a great time.

The weather was nice and sunny today.

Ride on our homestead.

3/2 - 14 - 6 w.g.

The weather was nice and sunny today.

farming
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Once a week

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Married at Cumberland Ont.
   Husband Selden C Chamberlin

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   One sister and brother-in-law.
   He was a teacher taught close around Calgary.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?
   Some where around 1915 or 1916 we had a post office in the Community
   The flats.
   And some for a while we took turns bringing the mail from a post office.
   The following well once a week later someone took over getting the mail themselves.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   We had church in summer and attended each Sunday. We visited neighbors occasionally with in 3 or 4 miles travelling by stone boat or horse & buggy.
21. How often did you visit relatives or friends in your old home?

Once a week

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west, tell when they came.

He was a teacher taught close around

23. In what particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Some where around 1915 or 1916 we had a post office in the community

24. Did you travel about much? In the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.)

We had church in summer and attended each Sunday. We visited neighbors occasionally with in 90% of mile by stone boat or horse buggy
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1916.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   My old — 25 miles Ernfold 20

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Later a new line came into the South and we traded some at St. Brevens and some at Ernfold and Morse. Then to Kelstern in 1923

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   One neighbour had a team of mules went to Moose Jaw every Saturday and we got mail & groceries other wise anyone going to get all the Saturdays.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly?
   About 1918 when most people around had cars

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   We've always bought clothing by mail and still do we need to also get some groceries by mail

32. When did you first have a telephone, and what company provided it?
   1918 Ernfold Rural Telephone Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   I expected to stay
24. How many times did you use the automobile in the community?

25. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

26. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

27. Did you travel by train or by automobile?

28. Did you ever take a New Year's trip to the ball and back?

34. Is reported to stay
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?
   Several People Moved Away and None of them Returned

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here giving dates wherever possible.
   We started a Ladies Aid in 1914 and I was first President. There had been a Grain Growers Society here around that time for the men.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)
   We had the first Radio.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any other names used since the first name was given; date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
   Goslin School District was named after one of the first teachers at Mr. Goslin's school. The flats post office - they claimed one of the first women to come here wore a pair of silk stockings. They called the district Silk Stocking Flats. The P. Office was just the flats. The Village of Kelowna started about 1922 named after a returned soldier but not from here.
34. Did any people move away during the 1920s? Did any return?

Several people moved away and some returned.

We started a garden club in 1917 and had a great time for the next few years.

We had the first radio.

1. Early School District was named after

2. Name of the first trustees a Mr. Gordon

3. Name of the first post office - they claimed one

4. The first woman to come here was

5. A pair of silk stockings they called the

6. Brother Buck blocking flats

The Village of Kelton started about 1922 and after a military soldier from here.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Don't know of any. There are only 2. Backlogs and our selves of the people who lived here first.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? .......

(indicate your preference if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, ages, and occupations.

We have 4 children

H. Evan Chamberlin - 2 mile west, farming

R. E. Chamberlin - Lives in part of this house

Mrs. John Haubrich - Zeneta, Saskatchewan

Mrs. O. L. Larson - Shamrock, Saskatchewan

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The houses we all lived in one roomed shacks

Modes of travel - Our radios

The Houses we all lived in one summer's night.
